title: Wildlands Field Studies in Chile
text:
I completed a 6 week immersive field study course in Northern Chilean Patagonia in winter 2024. I received academic course credit while gaining invaluable hands on experience, friendships, personal growth, and field skills.
Some of the skills/aspects I am most proud of include:


observational skills and field notes
planning ahead and problem solving

















scientific process and data collection
backpacking, camping, and wilderness safety skills

















engaging with Patagonian culture and people
learning about broad environmental concepts like succession, volcanoes, glaciers, and climate, and applying them locally

















introspection and self-reflection
meeting like minded peers also entering the field of environmental studies

title: Rachel Brody
text:
I created this website to share my interests, skills, and experiences.


I was born and raised in Half Moon Bay, CA, but have spent that last four years attending the University of California, Santa Barbara pursuing a degree in environmental studies. I have many interests within the field of environmental studies, including wildlife conservation, glaciers, and climate change. In my free time, you can find me outside hiking, running, playing frisbee with my dog, backpacking, surfing, skiing, napping, or eating.



 BS in Environmental Studies (with honors) (2024) | University of California, Santa Barbara
 Minor in Latin American and Iberian Studies (2024) | University of California, Santa Barbara

title: Other Skills
text:
Coding
Although my coding journey is just beginning, I have already become apt at analyzing data, creating figures, and building websites (like this one!) in Rstudio. I know I have just scratched the surface of coding possibilities, but I have developed the foundational understanding and resourcefulness to learn new coding skills and I am excited to grow them! Here is an example of a figure I made.





 


Bilingualism
I am fluent in English and Spanish. My mother is a native Spanish speaker so I started speaking Spanish from a very early age. I also went to a Spanish immersion elementary school where I developed Spanish reading and writing proficiency. Being bilingual has enabled me to connect with a broader range of people and expose me to more ideas and cultures. This was part of what inspired me to pursue a minor in Latin American and Iberian Studies.



Writing
I have attached some pieces that showcase my writing.
This is a research paper I wrote about the role of bilingual education in the Chicano struggle for educational equity for a class called History of Chicanos that I took at UCSB. read
I took a conservation planning class at UCSB in which we worked for 10 weeks in groups to create a conservation plan. Ours focuses on conserving Giant Sea Bass in California kelp forests. This isnâ€™t all my writing as I worked with 4 other people, but most of it is and it exemplifies my ability to collaborate with others. read



Diving
I am PADI Advanced Open Water Certified and AAUS Scientific Diving Certified. I occasionally participate in Reef Check California dives but I mostly love to dive recreationally!

title: Internships
text:
Santa Barbara Long Term Ecological Research Intern (April 2023 - December 2023)









 My primary task was to identify and tag organisms in photos of the sea floor at various long-term research sites in the Santa Barbara Channel. I worked primarily remotely using ViQi AI software to do this. The aim of the project was to compile detailed ecological data about the same locations over decades to serve as baseline data for many different research projects and other practical applications.


 


Nursery Intern at the Southern African Foundation for the Conservation of Coastal Birds (January 2020 - March 2020)


  
I raised African penguin chicks that had been abandoned or hurt. Daily tasks included preparing food, feeding, cleaning, helping with vet checks, giving medication, and generally monitoring health and behavior. I worked primarily alone in the nursery. The hardest part was to not coddle the adorable chicks because that would reduce their chances of being able to survive in the wild.








 


Songbird Intern at the Santa Barbara Wildlife Care Network (January 2022 - April 2022)










I learned so much from working alongside long time bird rehabilitators not only about how to care for birds, but also about the native bird species in the area, their role in the ecosystem, and threats that they currently face. I helped feed, give medication, and clean enclosures for wounded or sick songbirds that were admitted to the facility.





(top photo from algaeplant.com)(bottom photo from SBWCN website)
